content.user_title: Apply SRE patterns for production reliability
content.value_statement: Managing production services requires reliable metrics, clear incident processes, and systematic learning from failures. This skill provides SLO definitions, error budget policies, postmortem templates, and Prometheus alerting patterns to help teams maintain service reliability.
actual_capabilities: Define SLO targets and calculate error budgets
Write blameless postmortems using structured templates
Set up multi-window burn rate alerts in Prometheus
Create SLO recording rules for availability and latency
Establish on-call policies and escalation procedures
limitations: Does not deploy or configure monitoring infrastructure
Does not execute incident response actions
Does not integrate with external incident management tools
Requires existing Prometheus and Grafana for alerting patterns

use_cases.title: Set up SLO alerting
use_cases.description: Define availability and latency SLOs with Prometheus recording rules and multi-window burn rate alerts

use_cases.title: Write postmortems
use_cases.description: Use blameless postmortem templates to document incidents, identify root causes, and track action items

use_cases.title: Manage error budgets
use_cases.description: Calculate error budgets, establish budget remaining policies, and prevent reliability degradation

prompt_templates.title: Define SLO targets
prompt_templates.prompt: Help me define SLO targets for my API service. We want 99.9% availability and 500ms latency for 99% of requests. Show me the error budget calculation and downtime expectations.

prompt_templates.title: Write incident postmortem
prompt_templates.prompt: Write a blameless postmortem for a 2-hour database outage that affected 5000 users. The root cause was a connection pool exhaustion. Include timeline, 5 whys, impact assessment, and action items.

prompt_templates.title: Create SLO alerts
prompt_templates.prompt: Create Prometheus recording rules and multi-window burn rate alerts for a 99.9% availability SLO. Include fast burn (14.4x) and slow burn (6x) alert configurations.

prompt_templates.title: Review incident response
prompt_templates.prompt: Review my team's incident response process. We have SEV1-SEV3 classifications but struggle with alert fatigue and slow escalations. Suggest improvements based on SRE best practices.

output_examples.input: Help me define SLO targets for our new checkout service
output: Suggested SLOs: 99.9% availability (43 min/month downtime), 99% of requests under 500ms
Policy: Freeze features when budget drops below 10%
Recommended alerts: Multi-window burn rate (5m/1h) for fast detection
Postmortem trigger: Any SEV1/SEV2 incident or outage over 15 minutes

best_practices: Start with 99.9% SLO targets and adjust based on error budget consumption patterns
Use multi-window burn rate alerts to reduce false positives while maintaining fast detection
Write postmortems for all incidents including near-misses to identify failure patterns early
anti_patterns: Aiming for 100% reliability eliminates error budget and prevents any feature development
Skipping postmortems for minor incidents misses opportunities to improve detection and prevention
Alerting on SLI values directly instead of burn rates creates noisy or slow-to-trigger alerts

faq.question: What SLO percentage should I start with?
faq.answer: Start with 99.9% (43 min/month downtime). Higher targets cost exponentially more to maintain.

faq.question: How do I calculate error budget?
faq.answer: Error budget = 1 - SLO target. For 99.9% SLO, error budget is 0.1% = 43 minutes per month.

faq.question: Can this skill deploy Prometheus rules?
faq.answer: No. The skill provides Prometheus rule configurations as YAML templates. You must deploy them using your existing tooling.

faq.question: Is my data safe with this skill?
faq.answer: Yes. This is a documentation-only skill. It reads no user data, makes no network calls, and writes no files.

faq.question: Why use multi-window burn rate alerts?
faq.answer: Single-window alerts are either too noisy (short window) or too slow (long window). Multi-window combines both for faster detection with fewer false positives.

faq.question: How is this different from scaffolding skills?
faq.answer: This skill focuses on operational patterns for running services. Use scaffolding skills to create new services and this skill to manage their reliability.
